0	http://reuters.com/article/us-cyber-heist-g20-exclusive-idUSKCN1142A0	Exclusive: Six U.S. senators urge Obama to prioritize cyber crime at G20 summit	"
By Jonathan Spicer
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK Six U.S. senators have urged President Barack Obama to prioritize cyber crime at this weekend's Group of 20 summit in China
column2: in the wake of the theft of $81 million from Bangladesh's central bank
column3: according to a letter obtained by Reuters.In the letter sent to the White House ahead of the Sept. 4-5 summit
column4: Sherrod Brown
column5: a senior Democrat on the Senate Banking Committee
column6: and five other Democratic senators say they want the U.S. president to press leaders from the world's 20 biggest economies to commit in joint communiques to a ""coordinated strategy to combat cyber-crime at critical financial institutions.""The letter
column8: suggests that concern among U.S. lawmakers is growing over the February incident in which hackers breached Bangladesh Bank's systems and used the SWIFT banking network to request nearly $1 billion from an account held at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.Some of the dozens of orders were filled
column9: with much of the lost $81 million disappearing into Philippines casinos - prompting months of international finger-pointing
column11: and several requests from members of Congress for answers from the Fed and from SWIFT
column12: the secure messaging service that banks use to transfer money around the world.""Our financial institutions are connected in order to facilitate global commerce
column13: but cyber criminals - whether independent or state-sponsored - imperil this international system in a way few threats have
column15: headed by Gary Peters of Michigan
column16: wrote in the letter to Obama.""We strongly urge you to work with your counterparts and prioritize this discussion at the G20 leaders level in September
column17: it said of the summit to be held in Hangzhou
column19: adding that ""executive leadership circles across the globe"" needed to pay more attention to the risks.A senator in the Philippines has said Chinese hackers were likely to have pulled off the Bangladesh Bank heist
column20: citing a network of Chinese people involved in the routing of the stolen funds through Manila.Beijing has dismissed the suggestion.Copies of the letter from the U.S. senators were also sent to Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen and U.S. Treasury Secretary Jack Lew.

column1: OBAMA-XI TALKS
The other senators signing the letter were Mark Warner and Martin Heinrich
column2: both members of the Senate's Select Committee on Intelligence; Kirsten Gillibrand and Debbie Stabenow
column3: the ranking Democrat on the Senate's Committee on Agriculture
column4: Nutrition
column5: and Forestry.The White House expects G20 members at the summit ""to affirm their commitment to cooperate to fight cybercrime and to enhance confidence and trust in the digital economy
column6: a senior administration official said.

column1: Asked generally about cyber security on Monday
column2: White House spokesman Josh Earnest said at a press conference: ""I would anticipate that this issue more generally will be on the agenda"" when Obama meets Chinese President Xi Jinping
column3: the G20 summit host
column4: later this week. At a November summit
column5: the G20 pledged not to conduct economically motivated cyber espionage
column6: an agreement intended to reduce the estimated hundreds of billions of dollars worth of commercial trade secrets that are stolen by foreign governments seeking to benefit industry in their own countries. Since then
column7: the Bangladesh Bank attack and others that have emerged are only some of the threats posed by cyber criminals
column8: the senators wrote. World regulators should ""erect more robust defenses and collaborative systems to prevent and mitigate the impact of successful attacks
column10: noting that steps already taken by SWIFT are not enough.Bangladesh said it supported raising the issue at G20.""In most cases
column11: cyber attacks and crimes take place from outside the country
column13: a junior government minister for information and communications technology.

column1: So while addressing fast growing cyber attacks
column2: there should be a coordinated approach involving global stakeholders."" The Fed and other U.S. regulators said in a letter last week they were focused on cyber risks and controls at banks in the wake of the Bangladesh incident
column3: though they offered few specifics. Peters
column4: a member of the Senate's Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs
column5: told Reuters he is considering requesting a committee hearing on the heist.""I am concerned about the response and what steps have been taken to make sure it doesn't happen again
column6: he said in an interview. ""You just need more collaboration and sharing of information... because often times all these entities aren't talking to each other.""(This story has been refiled with full name of Bangladesh minister) (Reporting by Jonathan Spicer; Additional reporting by Roberta Rampton and Dustin Volz in Washington and Serajul Quadir in Dhaka; Editing by Bernard Orr

column1: 2	http://reuters.com/article/us-people-weiner-idUSKCN1141QT	Clinton aide Abedin leaves husband Weiner after sexting report	"
By Amanda Becker
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Huma Abedin
column2: one of Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton's top aides
column3: said on Monday that she was separating from her husband
column4: Anthony Weiner
column5: after a sex scandal similar to an earlier incident that led him to resign from the U.S. Congress.""After long and painful consideration and work on my marriage
column6: I have made the decision to separate from my husband
column7: Huma Abedin said in a statement.  ""Anthony and I remain devoted to doing what is best for our son
column8: who is the light of our life. During this difficult time
column9: I ask for respect for our privacy
column10: Abedin added.Abedin's announcement follows a New York Post report late Sunday that Weiner recently sent photos of his boxer-brief-clad genitals - one while he was in bed with their toddler son - via Twitter to another woman.

column1: The photos were part of a months-long exchange between Weiner and the woman and many of the messages were sexual in nature
column2: according to the Post report.Weiner resigned in June 2011 from Congress
column3: where he represented a New York City district
column4: followed a sexting scandal in which he accidentally posted an explicit photo of himself on his public Twitter timeline instead of via a direct message to a woman
column5: as he had intended.When Weiner made a second unsuccessful run for New York City mayor
column6: explicit photos surfaced in July 2013 that he had recently sent under the pseudonym ""Carlos Danger"" to a young woman in Indiana.

column1: Weiner said he had undergone therapy after the first sexting scandal
column2: according to media reports. In recent months
column3: he has taken care of the couple's toddler son. Abedin often travels with the Clinton campaign.Clinton's Republican rival
column4: Donald Trump
column5: said in a statement
column6: ""Huma is making a very wise decision. I know Anthony Weiner well
column7: and she will be far better off without him.""

column1: Abedin first worked for Clinton in the 1990s as an intern when Clinton was first lady. She was a personal aide to Clinton during her successful 2000 campaign for U.S. Senate. Abedin worked on Clinton's first
column2: unsuccessful White House bid in 2008 and served as her deputy chief of staff at the U.S. State Department. She is now the vice chair of Clinton's presidential campaign. Weiner served in Congress
column3: representing his district in New York City from 1999 to 2011. His first unsuccessful run for New York mayor was in 2005. (Reporting by Amanda Becker; Editing by Caren Bohan and Jonathan Oatis)"

column1: 3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-cybersecurity-idUSKCN1141L4	FBI detects breaches against two state voter systems	"
By Dustin Volz and Jim Finkle
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON The Federal Bureau of Investigation has found breaches in Illinois and Arizona's voter registration databases and is urging states to increase computer security ahead of the Nov. 8 presidential election
column2: according to a U.S. official familiar with the probe.The official
column3: speaking on condition of anonymity
column4: said on Monday that investigators were also seeking evidence of whether other states may have been targeted.The FBI warning in an Aug. 18 flash alert from the agency's Cyber Division did not identify the intruders or the two states targeted.Reuters obtained a copy of the document after Yahoo News first reported the story Monday.Accessing information in a voter database
column5: much of which is publicly accessible
column6: does not necessarily suggest an effort to manipulate the votes themselves. When registering
column10: and party affiliations. But U.S. intelligence officials have become increasingly worried that hackers sponsored by Russia or other countries may attempt to disrupt the presidential election. Officials and cyber security experts say recent breaches at the Democratic National Committee and elsewhere in the Democratic Party were likely carried out by people within the Russian government. Kremlin officials have denied that.

column1: An FBI spokeswoman would not comment on the alerts but said the agency ""routinely advises"" on ""various cyber threat indicators observed during the course of our investigations.""The intrusions come amid repeated unsubstantiated claims by Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump that the U.S. election system is ""rigged.""Trump has cited emails leaked from the DNC that indicated the party leadership favored Hillary Clinton over rival candidate Bernie Sanders as reason to cast doubt on the electoral process in general.
'LARGER ATTACK'?
David Kennedy
column2: chief executive officer of information security consulting company TrustedSec
column3: said the attacks referenced in the FBI alert appeared to be largely exploratory and not especially sophisticated.""It could be a precursor to a larger attack
column4: he added.Citing a state election board official
column5: Yahoo News said the Illinois voter registration system was shut down for 10 days in late July after hackers downloaded personal data on up to 200
column6: 000 voters.

column1: State voter systems are often targeted by hackers
column2: and 200
column3: 000 is a relatively small number compared to other recent incidents. An independent computer security researcher uncovered in December of last year a database on 191 million voters that was exposed on the open Internet due to an incorrect configuration.The Arizona attack was more limited and involved introducing malicious software into one state employee's computer
column4: said Matt Roberts
column5: communications director for the Arizona secretary of state's office. That office publicly reported a cyber incident in June after being contacted by the FBI
column6: which led to it temporarily shutting down its election site to deal with the potential threat. Roberts said he was uncertain if the FBI advisory was in reference to that same June incident
column7: during which investigators found no evidence of any data exfiltration. In that episode
column8: the FBI told Arizona officials the hackers were believed to be Russian and described it as an ""eight out of 10"" on a threat severity scale
column9: Roberts said.Arizona will hold Republican and Democratic primaries for congressional races on Tuesday.     (Reporting by Dustin Volz and Jim Finkle; Additional reporting by John Walcott; Editing by Lisa Von Ahn and Alistair Bell)"

column1: 4	http://reuters.com/article/us-california-farmworkers-overtime-idUSKCN1142EU	California lawmakers send governor bill authorizing farmworker overtime	"
SACRAMENTO
column2: Calif. California would become the first U.S. state to require farmers to pay overtime to field workers and fruit pickers under a bill approved by the legislature on Monday and sent to Democratic Governor Jerry Brown for his approval.The bill
column3: which passed on a mostly party-line vote
column4: would phase in overtime pay for farmworkers from 2019 to 2022. Small farms that employ 25 or fewer workers would have an additional three years to phase in the pay.If signed into law by Brown
column5: California
column6: the largest U.S. agricultural producer
column7: would the first state in the country to require farmers to pay overtime to laborers who work more than eight hours a day or 40 hours a week. The governor has not said if he will sign the measure.The bill is the culmination of decades of lobbying and pressure by the United Farmworkers Union.The Democratic-controlled legislature rejected a version of the same bill earlier this year
column8: but supporters amended it to phase in the overtime rules more slowly.

column1: Opponents said that requiring farmers to pay overtime could damage the state's agricultural economy
column2: where workers toil up to 60 hours a week during the harvest season but can go for months without pay other times of the year.They predicted that farmers would be forced to cut workers' hours to just 40 hours a week to avoid having to pay time-and-a-half or double-time overtime.Supporters
column3: mostly Democrats
column4: said the issue was one of fairness to farmworkers
column5: who are among the few U.S. hourly workers not paid overtime.

column1: For me
column2: it is a vote about my conscience
column3: said Democratic Assemblyman Eduardo Garcia. ""We will be improving the lives of people.""

column1: (Reporting by Sharon Bernstein; Editing by Bill Rigby and Peter Cooney)"
5	http://reuters.com/article/us-eu-usa-ttip-europeancommission-idUSKCN114143	European Commission says 'ball still rolling' on trade deal with U.S.	"
BRUSSELS The European Union's executive said on Monday it had a unanimous mandate from the bloc's 28 members to finalize negotiations on a free trade deal with the United States
column2: a day after Germany's economy minister said the talks had ""de facto failed"".Sigmar Gabriel of Germany
column3: the EU's biggest economy
column4: said on Sunday that negotiations over the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) had failed because Europe rejected some U.S. demands.Asked to comment on Gabriel's remarks
column5: a European Commission spokesman said: ""The ball is still rolling"" on TTIP.""Although trade talks take time
column6: the ball is rolling right now and the Commission is making steady progress in the ongoing TTIP negotiations
column7: Margaritis Schinas told a news conference.The White House also disputed Gabriel's contention
column8: saying it was still aiming to reach a deal by the end of the year. ""It's going to require the resolution of some pretty thorny negotiations
column9: but the president and his team are committed to doing that
column10: White House spokesman Josh Earnest told reporters in Washington.In Berlin
column11: Germany's leading industry associations were critical of Gabriel's remarks and urged the German government to show greater commitment to free trade deals.

column1: The head of industry association BDI
column2: Ulrich Grillo
column3: said it was ""astonishing"" that Gabriel
column4: who is also vice chancellor and head of the co-governing Social Democrats
column5: had declared the TTIP talks a failure when negotiations were still going on.Top officials of other industry associations such as VDMA and the Auto Industry Association VDA also spoke out against Gabriel's comments
column6: which highlighted growing divisions within Chancellor Angela Merkel's ruling coalition ahead of next year's elections.  Three years of negotiations have failed to resolve multiple differences
column7: including over food and environmental safety
column8: with critics saying the pact would hand too much power to big multinationals at the expense of consumers and workers.

column1: Backers of a sweeping U.S.-EU free trade deal see it bringing economic gains on both sides of the Atlantic. EU trade ministers will discuss the issue in Bratislava on Sept. 22.Schinas said the Commission was still ready to finalize the deal by the end of the year but not at the expense of ""Europe's safety
column2: health
column3: social and data protection standards
column4: or our cultural diversity"".

column1: Commenting separately on Gabriel's remarks
column2: Lithuanian Foreign Minister Linas Linkevicius said he believed arriving at a deal would benefit both the EU and the United States.""It would be better for all sides to agree
column3: he said. ""Of course
column4: not at an expense of our interests. We have to defend our interests
column5: but we also have to negotiate and conclude this agreement. It would be a big boost for economies
column6: jobs
column7: trade.""Britain's June vote to leave the EU has further clouded the picture
column8: although Schinas said Brussels was still negotiating on behalf of all 28 members of the bloc
column9: including London. (Reporting by Gabriela Baczynska; Additional reporting by Michael Nienaber in Berlin
column10: Nerijus Adomaitis in Oslo and Tim Ahmann in Washington; Editing by Peter Cooney)"

column1: 6	http://reuters.com/article/us-g20-china-obama-erdogan-idUSKCN11421W	Obama to meet Turkey's Erdogan in China on September 4	"

WASHINGTON U.S. President Barack Obama will have a bilateral meeting with Turkish President Tayyip Erdogan during the G20 summit in China next month and is likely to have at least an informal talk with Russia's Vladimir Putin
column2: the White House said on Monday.  Obama wants to talk with Erdogan about events in Turkey after July's attempted coup
column3: the military campaign against Islamic State
column4: and how to promote stability in Syria
column5: Deputy National Security Advisor Ben Rhodes told reporters. The White House said it opposes Turkey's push into areas in northern Syria controlled by the Syrian Democratic Forces
column6: or SDF
column7: an opposition group the Obama administration supports
column8: as it stands to erode the united front against Islamic State.  The Obama-Erdogan meeting is scheduled for Sunday.

column1: It was not certain whether Obama would hold a formal meeting with the Russian president during the G20 summit of the world's biggest economies
column2: which runs Sept 4-5. But the two leaders often speak on the margins of such summits
column3: Rhodes said. ""We usually try to find an opportunity for the two leaders to try to spend some time together
column4: usually to focus on Syria and Ukraine
column5: Rhodes said. The United States is at odds with Russia over the eastern Ukraine conflict and Washington and Moscow have struggled to stop fighting in Syria's civil war.

column1: Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said a meeting between Putin and Obama has not yet been coordinated
column2: Russian RIA news agency reported. ""We are ready
column3: RIA cited Peskov as saying. ""But there is no final agreement yet.""

column1: (Reporting by Roberta Rampton and Timothy Gardner in Washington; Additional reporting by Lidia Kelly in Moscow; Editing by Chris Reese
column2: Alistair Bell and Richard Balmforth)"

column1: 7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-autos-emissions-idUSKCN1142BW	Congressional leaders ask for more time to study new fuel rules	"

DETROIT Three Congressional leaders on Monday asked top federal environmental and safety officials to extend by 60 days the public comment period on new vehicle emissions and fuel economy standards.The public and their advocates need more time
column2: beyond the comment period that ends Sept. 26
column3: to absorb more than 1
column4: 000 pages of a draft technical assessment report
column5: the three said in a letter to the environmental and safety chiefs.A week ago
column6: U.S. regulators denied a similar request for an extension by major automakers.The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said in a July report that automakers have the technology to meet aggressive mandates to hike fuel efficiency
column7: but improvements will not be as great as the Obama administration once forecast because buyers are switching to pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles from lighter cars.

column1: When the administration first outlined its goal of boosting average fleet fuel economy to 54.5 miles per gallon
column2: regulators forecast that 67 percent of vehicles sold in 2025 would be cars.    Since then
column3: gasoline prices have fallen and truck and SUV sales have surged.

column1: Regulators now estimate the fleet will average 50 to 52.6mpg in 2025.

The letter dated Monday was sent to EPA Administrator Gina McCarthy and National Highway Traffic Safety Administration Administrator Mark Rosekind. It was signed by three members of the U.S. House of Representatives: Fred Upton
column2: chairman of the Committee on Energy and Commerce; Ed Whitfield
column3: chairman of the Subcommittee on Energy and Power; and Michael Burgess
column4: chairman of the Subcommittee on Commerce
column5: Manufacturing and Trade. (Reporting by Bernie Woodall; Editing by Tom Brown)"

column1: 8	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-prisons-immigration-idUSKCN1141W7	U.S. to review use of private immigration prisons
column2: shares slide	"

column1: By Julia Edwards
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON The U.S. Department of Homeland Security will study whether to discontinue using privately run detention centers
column2: which the Justice Department recently called unsafe
column3: for migrants and shares of private prison operators fell on Monday after the news.Department Secretary Jeh Johnson said he directed his advisory council to evaluate whether the agency should continue to contract with private prison operators and make a recommendation by Nov. 30. Advocates for immigrants have accused the companies of withholding proper mental health and medical care from detainees to boost profits. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE)
column4: a division of DHS
column5: currently uses detention facilities run by Corrections Corp of America (CXW.N) and The GEO Group (GEO.N). Corrections Corp of America's stock slid 9.4 percent and The GEO Group's stock fell 6 percent immediately after news of the review. Both stocks were rebounding later in the afternoon.Corrections Corp of America earned $689 million from ICE contracts since 2008
column6: 12 percent of its revenue from state and federal contracts over that time
column7: according to the website SmartProcure which tracks government contracts. The company currently manages a facility for Central American women and children in Dilley
column8: Texas.The GEO Group runs a similar facility in Karnes City
column9: Texas and has earned $1.18 billion from contracts with ICE since 2008
column10: about 35 percent of its total revenue from government contracts

column1: The GEO Group said in a statement
column2: ""GEO's facilities under contract with ICE are highly rated and provide high-quality
column3: cost-effective services in safe
column4: secure
column5: and humane residential environments pursuant to strict contractual requirements and the federal government's national standards
column6: the statement said. Corrections Corp of America spokesman Steve Owen said
column7: ""We're proud of the quality and value of the services we provide and look forward to sharing that information.""       Immigration advocates and members of Congress have ramped up pressure on DHS to end its contracts with the private prison companies since the Justice Department announced on Aug. 18 it would do so.

column1: That was prompted by an inspector general's report that criticized the safety and effectiveness of private prisons. ""Rather than wait for a review and a report from a committee
column2: the president should ensure that the phase-out of private prisons ... is extended to DHS operations immediately
column3: said Greg Chen
column4: advocacy director at the American Immigration Lawyers Association. Senator Bernie Sanders
column5: former Democratic presidential candidate
column6: and Democratic Representative Raul Grijalva asked DHS in a letter last week to end the practice.

column1: A Department of Homeland Security official told Reuters on Aug. 19 that ICE needed private prison companies because they offer flexibility to quickly build facilities and adjust detention space as migration flows fluctuate. Both companies also contract with state and local prison systems
column2: which make up about half of their revenue.A Reuters survey of 10 states with the largest contracts with private prison companies
column3: including California and Texas
column4: showed none had immediate plans to drop their contracts. (Reporting by Julia Edwards
column5: additional reporting by Mica Rosenberg; Editing by Cynthia Osterman and David Gregorio)"

column1: 9	http://reuters.com/article/us-laos-obama-philippines-idUSKCN11422C	Obama to meet Philippines' Duterte
column2: broach human rights	"

column1: WASHINGTON U.S. President Barack Obama is expected to meet with Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte on Sept. 6
column2: and plans to touch on human rights as well as security concerns
column3: the White House said on Monday.""We absolutely expect that the president will raise concerns about some of the recent statements from the president of the Philippines
column4: White House Deputy National Security Adviser Ben Rhodes told a media briefing when asked whether inflammatory remarks by Duterte about women
column5: journalists and others would be a topic of discussion.Rhodes said
column6: however
column7: that there were important security issues to cover as well
column8: particularly tensions over navigation in the South China Sea. China has been incensed by a ruling against its claims in the South China Sea by an international court

column1: The expected meeting between Obama and Duterte would take place in Laos
column2: where the two leaders will be attending a summit of leaders from Pacific Rim nations.

column1: (Reporting by Roberta Rampton; Writing by Tim Ahmann; Editing by Chris Reese and Andrew Hay)"
